scenario: Progressive's stock price dropped 4% after a downgrade by analyst Meyer Shields from Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, who now rates the company as market perform (hold) instead of outperform (buy). Shields maintained a price target of $288 per share, citing concerns over slowing growth of in-force auto policies and pressure on earned rates due to increased claims and moderating rate increases from competitors. However, other analysts raised their price targets, with some expressing confidence in Progressive's management to find new sources of revenue and profitability. The stock closed lower despite the S&P 500 index rising 0.1%.
